abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            unsatisfactory, sustainability unlikely, and institutional
            development impact negligible. Although the project
            contributed to a number of policy reforms, its principal
            objective of delivering agricultural services to
            small-holders, particularly the poor, was not achieved, and
            the absence of specific performance indicators, retrains an
            assessment on the extent of small-holder productivity,
            incomes, and food security. Lessons drawn from the project
            address, in general, the basics in project design, that is,
            the realistic assessment of management capacity,
            particularly as it involves institutional reform, and,
            stakeholders involvement in its conceptualization. In
            particular, regarding matters of policy reforms, substantial
            reforms need to be further addressed, since those reforms
            implemented under the project, will not contribute
            significantly to the sector. Research and extension lessons,
            suggest the need to improve funding procedures, to
            strengthen farmers participation in the development of
            research agendas, and, to clearly define public funded
            extension priorities, as well as partnerships between
            government, non-governmental organizations, and the private
            sector. Concerning the Bank, as it relates to effective
            supervision, it is suggested that additional resources
            should be allocated to project supervision, when it
            substantially deviates from its initial objectives.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's key objectives are:
            (a) to help formulate and implement institutional and
            management reforms in the national research, extension, and
            input supply systems, with the aim of providing
            cost-effective and sustainable technologies suitable for a
            range of smallholders; and (b) to enhance farm incomes and
            food security by increasing and diversifying smallholder
            production, especially among female and resource-poor
            farmers.  A secondary objective is to provide a policy and
            operational framework for channeling and coordinating
            assistance to the development of agricultural services from
            other donors.  The project will be implemented over a six
            year period and will be comprised of four major components:
            research, extension, input supply and institutional strengthening.
